title: So I finally got a new monitor...
content:
And, as nifty and useful as it is, decided to take a look at my old Keen drawings that some of you might remember from a few years ago. Not as nice looking now as they seemed back then, in retrospect. As it turns out, the old monitor apparently had really, really bad contrast. So I take a look at the CK4 title screen remake, only to be horrified by the knowledge that most of the outlines were this hideous brown, which had appeared as black on the old hardware. Why the heck no one bothered pointing this out in the first place is beyond me, since it ruined the picture.

So, two years after the fact, [img]http://img445.imageshack.us/my.php?image=ck4title7ou.png[/img], in the odd event that any of you actually care. The old version is still up [url=http://dosclassics.com/keen/art.php]here[/url] at BtP, for comparison.

And since it's semi-related and not immediately repulsive, I'll go ahead and repost [img]http://img445.imageshack.us/my.php?image=lazyday7vi.png[/img] for the heck of it.

And if anyone is interested, I drew the CK6 title screen up at around the same time, but never did anything with it. If there's any demand for a finished version, I'd be willing to give it a go.

content: Wow that new version does look a lot better.  Funny coincidence though, I spent all morning today pulling my monitor apart to try to fix it.  The red colour started playing up almost exactly a week ago giving me a kind of a random cyan haze over the screen (lack of the colour red), so last night I finally gave in and [img]http://www.shikadi.net/pics/complicated.jpg[/img].  A couple of hours later with the help of my soldering iron and it [img]http://www.shikadi.net/pics/working.jpg[/img].  Yay! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Gaa...
content:
Wow... I never would do that; I'd get a new monitor first (I know where I can get them for free if I need them - My niegbor helps dispose of computer equipment, and many of his items work quite well, but his costomer wanted an LCD, or vise-versa).

I really don't know the difference.

BTW - I have a 'VeiwSonic UltraBrite A70f+'

It has an ultra-brite option which makes the screen very brilliant. I'd recomend it; very good graphics for an analog.

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: So I finally got a new monitor...

title: Mon It ORRR!
content:
I've been customising a few of my monitors lately. The brightness and focus are the more frequent issues, so my policy now is to heat up the end of a screwdriver over a candle with which to drill a couple of holes in the back of the monitor case aligning with the brighness and focus knobs.

Currently I'm using a 17", with a generally imperceptible 1.5cm scratch in the very middle, that occasionally starts emitting a high-pitched noise that seems to hide if I tilt the screen up alot, or on a slight angle to the left, and only disappears either randomly or after being turned off for a few minutes.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: Mon It ORRR!
content:
I imagine Billy's shed to have a similar appearance as well. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

As for the monitor, pretty much everybody with a little knowhow tells me (or anybody) else not to fool around with TVs or computer monitors, as there are very high voltages involved, even when turned off, even after a few years.
That was enough to "scare" me into not opening any.
I think over here you also need to be certified somehow if you want to legally work on TVs/monitors.
I'm not completely sure about that part though...

Anyway, as long as you know what you're doing... (I hope so!)Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Mon It ORRR!
content:
"as there are very high voltages involved"

OH yeah - remember in Jurassic Park how the electric fences had on them "Danger! 10,000 volts" - well the monitor in the photos runs on 27,500 volts...

And that's correct, you shouldn't 'fool around' with them, but as with most things using some common sense goes a long way... (and a little electrical know-how helps too.) I don't think you need to be certified to work on your own TVs/monitors though, but you certainly do if you're doing it for a living.
